message.content: We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest a diagnosis of acute rheumatic fever, which is associated with interstitial myocardial granulomas containing plump macrophages with nuclei incorporating central wavy ribbons of chromatin. Option A is associated with infectious mononucleosis, option B with malaria, and option C with gout.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms suggest the patient has systemic inflammation, joint pain, and a pericardial friction rub, which is highly indicative of systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE). Interstitial myocardial granulomas containing plump macrophages with nuclei incorporating central wavy ribbons of chromatin are histopathologic findings commonly associated with SLE. Option A describes infectious mononucleosis, option B describes malaria, and option C describes gout.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient’s symptoms, including sore throat, joint pain, bumps on elbows, chest pain that is relieved by leaning forward, and pericardial friction rub suggest acute rheumatic fever, which is most commonly caused by Group A streptococcus infection. The histopathologic finding associated with this condition is interstitial myocardial granulomas containing plump macrophages with nuclei incorporating central wavy ribbons of chromatin.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The patient presents with sore throat, joint pain, bumps on elbows, pericardial friction rub, and pain in the center of his chest that is relieved with leaning forward. These symptoms suggest acute rheumatic fever. The histopathologic finding associated with this condition is interstitial myocardial granulomas containing plump macrophages with nuclei incorporating central wavy ribbons of chromatin. Atypical lymphocytes noted on peripheral blood smear with an initial positive heterophil antibody test is associated with infectious mononucleosis. Plasmodium falciparum ring forms in red blood cells on peripheral blood smear is associated with malaria. Needle-shaped, negatively birefringent crystal deposits surrounded by palisading histiocytes in the synovial fluid of an affected joint is associated with gout.

We refer to Wikipedia articles on medicine for help. The symptoms, including sore throat, joint pain, and pericardial friction rub suggest rheumatic fever, which is associated with granulomatous inflammation in the heart, called Aschoff bodies. Option A describes infectious mononucleosis, option B describes malaria, and option C describes gout.
